deck.name: Combat First Aid & TCCC
deck.description: TC 4-02.1 & ATP 4-02.5 - Tactical Combat Casualty Care, MARCH, hemorrhage control, airway, chest injuries, shock, burns, and MEDEVAC

metadata.title: First Aid / Tactical Combat Casualty Care
metadata.note: TCCC guidelines updated regularly - verify current guidance

cards.front: What does MARCH stand for?
cards.back:
Massive hemorrhage, Airway, Respiration, Circulation, Hypothermia/Head injury.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-1)

cards.front: What are the three phases of TCCC?
cards.back:
Care Under Fire (CUF), Tactical Field Care (TFC), Tactical Evacuation Care (TACEVAC).

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 2, para 2-5)

cards.front: What is the ONLY intervention during Care Under Fire?
cards.back:
Stop life-threatening hemorrhage with tourniquet. Return fire and move to cover.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-4)

cards.front: What is Care Under Fire?
cards.back:
Care provided while under hostile fire. Limited to hemorrhage control and movement.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 2, para 2-6)

cards.front: What is Tactical Field Care?
cards.back:
Care when no longer under direct fire. Allows full MARCH assessment and treatment.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 4, para 4-1)

cards.front: What is TACEVAC?
cards.back:
Tactical Evacuation Care - care provided during casualty transport to higher level.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 5, para 5-1)

cards.front: Where should a tourniquet be placed?
cards.back:
HIGH and TIGHT - 2-3 inches above the wound, over clothing if necessary.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-15)

cards.front: Can a tourniquet be placed over a joint?
cards.back:
No. Place above the joint if wound is near it.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-15)

cards.front: How long can a tourniquet remain in place?
cards.back:
Up to 2 hours with minimal risk. Do NOT loosen if evacuation delayed beyond 2 hours.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: How do you verify tourniquet is properly applied?
cards.back:
Bleeding stopped, no distal pulse, time marked on tourniquet or forehead.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-18)

cards.front: What is junctional hemorrhage?
cards.back:
Bleeding from areas where tourniquets cannot be applied: neck, axilla, groin.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-18)

cards.front: How do you treat junctional hemorrhage?
cards.back:
Direct pressure, wound packing with hemostatic gauze, pressure dressing.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-18)

cards.front: What is Combat Gauze?
cards.back:
Hemostatic (blood-clotting) gauze for wound packing.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-24)

cards.front: How do you apply hemostatic gauze?
cards.back:
Pack TIGHTLY into wound on bleeding source, apply pressure 3+ minutes, then pressure dressing.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-25)

cards.front: What is tension pneumothorax?
cards.back:
Air trapped in chest cavity, compressing lung and heart. Life-threatening emergency.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-30)

cards.front: What are signs of tension pneumothorax?
cards.back:
Severe respiratory distress, absent breath sounds on affected side, tracheal deviation, distended neck veins.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-31)

cards.front: How do you treat tension pneumothorax?
cards.back:
Needle decompression - 14-gauge needle at 2nd intercostal space midclavicular line.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-33)

cards.front: Where is needle decompression performed?
cards.back:
2nd intercostal space midclavicular line OR 5th intercostal space anterior axillary line.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-33)

cards.front: Why insert needle over TOP of rib?
cards.back:
To avoid intercostal blood vessels and nerves that run along bottom of ribs.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-34)

cards.front: What is an open chest wound?
cards.back:
Penetrating wound allowing air to enter chest cavity (sucking chest wound).

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-40)

cards.front: How do you treat an open chest wound?
cards.back:
Apply vented chest seal. If unavailable, tape occlusive dressing on THREE sides.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-42)

cards.front: What is a vented chest seal?
cards.back:
Occlusive dressing with one-way valve allowing air out but not in.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-41)

cards.front: Why tape on three sides only?
cards.back:
Creates flutter valve - air escapes on exhalation, seals on inhalation.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-42)

cards.front: What is the recovery position?
cards.back:
Unconscious breathing casualty placed on their side to maintain airway.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: When is the recovery position used?
cards.back:
Casualty unconscious but breathing, cannot constantly monitor airway, may vomit.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: What is a nasopharyngeal airway (NPA)?
cards.back:
Soft rubber tube inserted through nostril to maintain open airway.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: How do you size an NPA?
cards.back:
Measure from tip of nose to earlobe.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: Which nostril is preferred for NPA insertion?
cards.back:
RIGHT nostril, bevel toward septum. Use left if resistance.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: When is NPA contraindicated?
cards.back:
Suspected basal skull fracture (raccoon eyes, Battle's sign, CSF leak).

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-14)

cards.front: What is Battle's sign?
cards.back:
Bruising behind the ear - indicates basal skull fracture.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 5, para 5-3)

cards.front: What are raccoon eyes?
cards.back:
Bruising around both eyes - indicates basal skull fracture.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 5, para 5-3)

cards.front: What are signs of hypovolemic shock?
cards.back:
Altered mental status, pale/cold/clammy skin, rapid weak pulse, rapid shallow breathing.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What is delayed capillary refill?
cards.back:
More than 2 seconds for color to return after pressing fingernail - sign of shock.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 4, para 4-7)

cards.front: How do you treat shock in the field?
cards.back:
Control bleeding, position flat, prevent heat loss, IV/IO fluids if trained, do NOT give oral fluids.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 4, para 4-12)

cards.front: Why prevent heat loss in shock?
cards.back:
Hypothermia worsens blood clotting and cardiac function - part of lethal triad.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 4, para 4-10)

cards.front: What is the lethal triad of trauma?
cards.back:
Hypothermia, Acidosis, Coagulopathy - each worsens the others.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-45)

cards.front: What are the triage categories?
cards.back:
IMMEDIATE (Red/T1), DELAYED (Yellow/T2), MINIMAL (Green/T3), EXPECTANT (Black/T4).

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: What is IMMEDIATE (Red/T1) triage?
cards.back:
Life-threatening injury requiring immediate intervention to survive.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 5, para 5-9)

cards.front: What is DELAYED (Yellow/T2) triage?
cards.back:
Serious injury but can wait for treatment without immediate death.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 5, para 5-10)

cards.front: What is MINIMAL (Green/T3) triage?
cards.back:
Minor injuries - "walking wounded."

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 5, para 5-11)

cards.front: What is EXPECTANT (Black/T4) triage?
cards.back:
Unlikely to survive given available resources.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 5, para 5-12)

cards.front: What is Line 1 of the MEDEVAC 9-line?
cards.back:
Grid location of pickup site.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is Line 2 of the MEDEVAC 9-line?
cards.back:
Radio frequency and call sign.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is Line 3 of the MEDEVAC 9-line?
cards.back:
Number of patients by precedence (A, B, C, D, E).

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is Line 4 of the MEDEVAC 9-line?
cards.back:
Special equipment required.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is Line 5 of the MEDEVAC 9-line?
cards.back:
Number of patients by type (litter/ambulatory).

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What is Line 6 of the MEDEVAC 9-line?
cards.back:
Security of pickup site (N, P, E, X).

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: What does N mean in Line 6?
cards.back:
No enemy troops in area.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-10)

cards.front: What does P mean in Line 6?
cards.back:
Possible enemy troops - approach with caution.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-10)

cards.front: What does E mean in Line 6?
cards.back:
Enemy troops in area - armed escort required.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-10)

cards.front: What does X mean in Line 6?
cards.back:
Hot LZ - enemy troops, armed escort required.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-10)

cards.front: What is URGENT precedence?
cards.back:
Within 2 hours to save life, limb, or eyesight.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-6)

cards.front: What is PRIORITY precedence?
cards.back:
Within 4 hours - prevents deterioration.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-6)

cards.front: What is ROUTINE precedence?
cards.back:
Within 24 hours - no deterioration expected.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 6, para 6-6)

cards.front: What is the Rule of Nines for burns?
cards.back:
Head 9%, each arm 9%, chest 9%, abdomen 9%, back 18%, each leg 18%, groin 1%.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: How do you treat a burn casualty?
cards.back:
Stop burning, remove jewelry, cover with DRY sterile dressing, prevent hypothermia.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 6, para 6-12)

cards.front: Why NOT use wet dressings on large burns?
cards.back:
Risk of hypothermia - large wet area rapidly cools the body.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 6, para 6-12)

cards.front: Should you pop burn blisters?
cards.back:
No - blisters protect underlying tissue from infection.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 6, para 6-13)

cards.front: What are signs of heat stroke?
cards.back:
Temperature >104째F, hot/dry skin, altered mental status, rapid pulse.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 7, para 7-12)

cards.front: How do you treat heat stroke?
cards.back:
Move to shade, remove clothing, cool rapidly (ice packs to neck/armpits/groin), URGENT evacuation.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 7, para 7-14)

cards.front: What are the stages of hypothermia?
cards.back:
Mild (90-95째F): shivering. Moderate (82-90째F): confusion, stops shivering. Severe (<82째F): unconscious.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 7, para 7-22)

cards.front: Why handle hypothermia casualty GENTLY?
cards.back:
Cold heart is irritable - rough handling can cause cardiac arrest.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 7, para 7-25)

cards.front: How do you treat hypothermia?
cards.back:
Remove wet clothing, insulate from ground, apply heat to torso, give warm drinks if conscious.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 7, para 7-25)

cards.front: How do you treat a suspected fracture?
cards.back:
Check CSM, splint in position found, include joint above and below, recheck CSM.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 5, para 5-15)

cards.front: What is CSM?
cards.back:
Circulation, Sensation, Movement - checked before and after splinting.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 5, para 5-14)

cards.front: What does AVPU stand for?
cards.back:
Alert, Voice responsive, Pain responsive, Unresponsive (neurological status).

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 1, para 1-8)

cards.front: What is the leading cause of preventable death on the battlefield?
cards.back:
Hemorrhage (massive bleeding) - approximately 90% of preventable deaths.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 1, para 1-5)

cards.front: How do you perform head-tilt chin-lift?
cards.back:
Hand on forehead tilts head back, fingertips lift chin forward. Opens airway.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: When is head-tilt chin-lift contraindicated?
cards.back:
When cervical spine injury is suspected - use jaw thrust instead.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: How do you perform the jaw thrust?
cards.back:
Kneel above head, place fingers behind jaw angles, push jaw forward while keeping neck straight.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 3, para 3-7)

cards.front: What is normal adult heart rate?
cards.back:
60-100 beats per minute at rest.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 1, para 1-12)

cards.front: Where do you check for a radial pulse?
cards.back:
Inner wrist, below the thumb.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 1, para 1-12)

cards.front: What is the TCCC Card?
cards.back:
DD Form 1380 - documents all treatments, vitals, and medications given to casualty.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 4, para 4-30)

cards.front: What does the TCCC Card document?
cards.back:
ID, mechanism of injury, treatments, vitals, medications, tourniquet times.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 4, para 4-30)

cards.front: What is TXA (Tranexamic Acid)?
cards.back:
Anti-bleeding medication given IV for hemorrhagic shock. Must be given within 3 hours.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 4, para 4-20)

cards.front: When should tourniquet be converted to pressure dressing?
cards.back:
ONLY if: not in shock, wound amenable, <2 hours, controlled environment, evacuation not imminent.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 4, para 4-8)

cards.front: What is the Combat Wound Medication Pack?
cards.back:
Acetaminophen and Meloxicam for pain management.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 4, para 4-25)

cards.front: What antibiotic is given for penetrating wounds?
cards.back:
Moxifloxacin 400mg oral.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 4, para 4-26)

cards.front: What is the M in MARCH?
cards.back:
Massive hemorrhage - control life-threatening bleeding FIRST.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the A in MARCH?
cards.back:
Airway - ensure open airway.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-20)

cards.front: What is the R in MARCH?
cards.back:
Respiration - treat chest injuries and breathing problems.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-28)

cards.front: What is the C in MARCH?
cards.back:
Circulation - treat shock, establish IV access.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-40)

cards.front: What is the H in MARCH?
cards.back:
Hypothermia/Head injury - prevent heat loss, assess neurological status.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-45)

cards.front: What is the primary survey?
cards.back:
Rapid assessment: Massive hemorrhage, Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure.

(Source: ATP 4-02.5, Ch 3, para 3-2)

cards.front: What is the CAT tourniquet?
cards.back:
Combat Application Tourniquet - standard issue extremity tourniquet.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-12)

cards.front: How do you tighten the CAT tourniquet?
cards.back:
Pull strap tight, twist windlass until bleeding stops, secure windlass in clip.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-14)

cards.front: What do you write on the tourniquet?
cards.back:
Time of application (or mark on casualty's forehead).

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-18)

cards.front: What is a pressure dressing?
cards.back:
Bandage wrapped firmly to apply continuous pressure over wound.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: How do you treat a spinal injury?
cards.back:
Do NOT move unless necessary. Stabilize head/neck inline, log roll if needed.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: What are signs of closed head injury?
cards.back:
Altered consciousness, confusion, unequal pupils, CSF leak, nausea/vomiting.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 5, para 5-3)

cards.front: What is the best cooling method for heat stroke?
cards.back:
Cold water immersion (if available). Otherwise ice packs to neck, armpits, groin.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 7, para 7-14)

cards.front: Can you give oral fluids to a shock casualty?
cards.back:
No - nothing by mouth. Risk of aspiration if consciousness decreases.

(Source: TC 4-02.1, Ch 4, para 4-12)
